properties.name: Advice
properties.webBody:
This Advice message is being issued for Mount Buninyong.
  • This Advice message replaces the Advice message issued at 9:51am Friday 7 March.
  • The bushfire at Mount Buninyong remains under control.
  • Firefighters are remaining on scene to fully extinguish the fire.
There is currently no threat to you, but you should stay informed and plan for what you will do if the situation changes. 
What you should do: 
  • Monitor weather conditions and warnings. 
  • Review your fire survival plan. 
  • If you do not have a plan, decide what you will do if the situation changes.
Impacts in your area: 
  • Emergency services are continuing work on assessing and removing hazardous trees in the fire-impacted area. 
  • Bulldozers and aircraft are operating in the area.
  • Smoke will be visible from nearby communities and roads.
  •  The following roads are closed: 
    - Yendon No. 2 Road between Midland Highway and Wiggins Road.
    - The Mount Buninyong tourist road at Blackberry Lane to the top of Mt Buninyong.
  • Obey all road signage for community safety.
  • Check the VicTraffic website (www.traffic.transport.vic.gov.au) or call 13 11 70 for road closures.
This message was issued by Forest Fire Management Victoria.

The next update is expected by 10/03/2025 10:00 am or as the situation changes.

Use multiple sources to stay informed: 
  • www.emergency.vic.gov.au
  • VicEmergency Hotline - freecall 1800 226 226
  • VicEmergency app
  • Facebook or Twitter (#VicFires)
  • Tune in to ABC Local Radio, commercial and designated community radio stations, or Sky News TV.
Accessibility:
The following services can help you, or someone you know, access information during an emergency.
  • To access this information in other languages call the Translating and Interpreting Service on 131 450 (freecall) and ask them to call VicEmergency Hotline.
  • If you are deaf, hard of hearing, or have a speech/communication impairment contact National Relay Service on 1800 555 677 and ask them to call the VicEmergency Hotline.
properties.text:

Incident Location: Mount Buninyong
Issue Date: Saturday 08 March 2025, 08:59 am
Next Update: Monday 10 March 2025, 10:00 am

More details at http://emergency.vic.gov.au/respond/#!/warning/37083/moreinfo

This Advice message is being issued for Mount Buninyong.
- This Advice message replaces the Advice message issued at 9:51am Friday 7 March.
- The bushfire at Mount Buninyong remains under control.
- Firefighters are remaining on scene to fully extinguish the fire.


There is currently no threat to you, but you should stay informed and plan for what you will do if the situation changes.

properties.name: Community Information
properties.webBody:
This Community Information message is being issued for Jericho - Park Road. 
  • The bushfire at Park Road Jericho under control.
  • Firefighters remain in the area monitoring this fire and mopping up hot spots.
The Australian Alpine Walking Track is open via a temporarily detour using the Upper Thomson Road.  Signage is in place indicating this re-route.  

The following roads and tracks remain closed:
  • Trig Point Track
  • Cream Can Hill Track
  • Upper Thomson Road
  • Mt Gregory Track
  • Sucklings Road
  • Basalt Hill Track
  • Park Road
  • Section of Thomson-Jordan Road between Park Road and Basalt Hill Track
Check the VicTraffic website (traffic.vicroads.vic.gov.au/) or call 13 11 70 for road closures.   Check parks.vic.gov.au/coc-listing and ffm.vic.gov.au for Forest and Park closures.

This message replaces the Advice message issued at 11.00 am 2/03/25.   
There is no immediate threat to the community and no action is required.  


This message was issued by Forest Fire Management Victoria.

The next update is expected by 16/03/2025 06:00 pm or as the situation changes.

Use multiple sources to stay informed: 
  • www.emergency.vic.gov.au
  • VicEmergency Hotline - freecall 1800 226 226
  • VicEmergency app
  • Facebook or Twitter (#vicfires).
  • Tune in to ABC Local Radio, commercial and designated community radio stations, or Sky News TV.
Accessibility:
The following services can help you, or someone you know, access information during an emergency.
  • To access this information in other languages call the Translating and Interpreting Service on 131 450 (freecall) and ask them to call VicEmergency Hotline.  
  • If you are deaf, hard of hearing, or have a speech/communication impairment contact National Relay Service for assistance and ask them to call the VicEmergency Hotline.
properties.text: COMMUNITY INFORMATION - BUSHFIRE - Stay Informed Incident Location: Jericho - Park Road Issue Date: Sunday 09 March 2025, 06:55 pm Next Update: Sunday 16 March 2025, 06:00 pm More details at http://emergency.vic.gov.au/respond/#!/warning/37101/moreinfo This Community Information message is being issued for Jericho - Park Road. - The bushfire at Park Road Jericho under control. - Firefighters remain in the area monitoring this fire and mopping up hot spots. The Australian Alpine Walking Track is open via a temporarily detour using the Upper Thomson Road. Signage is in place indicating this re-route. The following roads and tracks remain closed: - Trig Point Track - Cream Can Hill Track - Upper Thomson Road - Mt Gregory Track - Sucklings Road - Basalt Hill Track - Park Road - Section of Thomson-Jordan Road between Park Road and Basalt Hill Track Check the VicTraffic website (traffic.vicroads.vic.gov.au/) or call 13 11 70 for road closures. Check parks.vic.gov.au/coc-listing and ffm.vic.gov.au for Forest and Park closures. This message replaces the Advice message issued at 11.00 am 2/03/25. properties.name: Advice
properties.location: Buragwonduc, Crookayan, Glencairn, Glenfalloch, Licola, Licola North, Nap Nap Marra, Sargood, Worrowing, Wrathung, Wrixon, Koorool, Tamboritha
properties.webBody:
This Advice message is being issued for Buragwonduc, Crookayan, Glencairn, Glenfalloch, Koorool, Licola, Licola North, Nap Nap Marra, Sargood, Tamboritha, Worrowing, Wrathung, Wrixon.

  • The bushfire at Mt Margaret Walking Track in the Alpine National Park is not yet under control.
  • Driven by very dry conditions, the fire remains active and has grown further to over 5500 hectares.
  • Assisted by aircraft, firefighters continue to work on strengthening containment lines along Mount Margaret Track, Tamboritha Road, Moroka Road, Mount Wellington Track, Avon Turton Divide Track and Mount Hump South Track. 
  • Back burning operations continue on the western and southern edge of the fire at Mt Margaret Track and Chromite Mine Track.
  • Heavy firefighting machinery and large vehicles are operating in the area on main roads and forest tracks.  
  • This message replaces the Advice Message issued at 2.00 pm 8/03/2025
There is currently no threat to local communities, but you should continue to stay informed and monitor weather conditions and warnings.

If the situation changes, campgrounds and roads may be closed at short notice.  Visitors should stay informed, monitor weather conditions and warnings, and remain ready and able to move away.  
What you should do: 
  • Review your fire survival plan. 
  • If you do not have a plan, decide what you will do if the situation changes.
  • Reduce speed and drive to the conditions, especially on narrow winding roads.
  • Watch for emergency response teams and follow their directions.
Impacts in your area: 

  • Firefighters, aircraft and plant machinery will remain working in the area.
  • You will see smoke in the area which can affect your health. If you are experience any symptoms that may be due to smoke exposure, seek medical advice or call NURSE-ON-CALL on 1300 60 60 24. 
Park Closures
  • Avon Wilderness Park is currently closed due to bushfire. 
  • Areas within the southern section of the Alpine National Park are also closed due to bushfire. 
Roads and track closures include

  • The Howitt Road is closed at Arbuckle Junction due to the current Wonnangatta Valley fire.  There is a Watch and Act in place for this area.  

  • The Tali Karng walking Track network 
  • Chromite Mine Track
  • B1 Track and B2 Track
  • Moroka Range Track 
  • Burgoyne track east of the Licola Road
  • Mt Margaret Track 
  • Mt Margaret Walking Track
  • Millers Hut
  • Nyimba Camp
  • Mt Wellington Track
  • Hickeys Creek Track and Hickeys Creek Track - East 
  • Avon Track
Check the VicTraffic website (traffic.vicroads.vic.gov.au/) or call 13 11 70 for road closures.   Check parks.vic.gov.au/coc-listing and ffm.vic.gov.au for Forest and Park closures. 

This message was issued by Forest Fire Management Victoria.

The next update is expected by 10/03/2025 03:00 pm or as the situation changes.

Use multiple sources to stay informed: 
  • www.emergency.vic.gov.au
  • VicEmergency Hotline - freecall 1800 226 226
  • VicEmergency app
  • Facebook or Twitter (#VicFires)
  • Tune in to ABC Local Radio, commercial and designated community radio stations, or Sky News TV.
Accessibility:
The following services can help you, or someone you know, access information during an emergency.
  • To access this information in other languages call the Translating and Interpreting Service on 131 450 (freecall) and ask them to call VicEmergency Hotline.
  • If you are deaf, hard of hearing, or have a speech/communication impairment contact National Relay Service on 1800 555 677 and ask them to call the VicEmergency Hotline.
properties.text:
ADVICE - BUSHFIRE - Stay Informed
Incident Location: Mt Margaret Walking Track
Issue Date: Sunday 09 March 2025, 04:53 pm
Next Update: Monday 10 March 2025, 03:00 pm

More details at http://emergency.vic.gov.au/respond/#!/warning/37097/moreinfo

This Advice message is being issued for Buragwonduc, Crookayan, Glencairn, Glenfalloch, Koorool, Licola, Licola North, Nap Nap Marra, Sargood, Tamboritha, Worrowing, Wrathung, Wrixon.

- The bushfire at Mt Margaret Walking Track in the Alpine National Park is not yet under control.
- Driven by very dry conditions, the fire remains active and has grown further to over 5500 hectares.
- Assisted by aircraft, firefighters continue to work on strengthening containment lines along Mount Margaret Track, Tamboritha Road, Moroka Road, Mount Wellington Track, Avon Turton Divide Track and Mount Hump South Track. 
- Back burning operations continue on the western and southern edge of the fire at Mt Margaret Track and Chromite Mine Track.
- Heavy firefighting machinery and large vehicles are operating in the area on main roads and forest tracks.  
- This message replaces the Advice Message issued at 2.00 pm 8/03/2025


There is currently no threat to local communities, but you should continue to stay informed and monitor weather conditions and warnings.

If the situation changes, campgrounds and roads may be closed at short notice.  Visitors should stay informed, monitor weather conditions and warnings, and remain ready and able to move away.

properties.name: Community Information
properties.webBody:
This Community Information message is being issued for Euroa, Violet Town, Longwood, Ruffy, Avenel and Strathbogie.
  • An outbreak of H7N8 avian influenza (bird flu) is confirmed at four poultry properties at Euroa. 
  • This warning is relevant for all bird owners including poultry producers, bird keepers and pet bird owners. 
  • The area impacted by restrictions is east of the Goulburn Valley Freeway for Strathbogie Shire.
  • This Community Information replaces the Community Information issued on 5 March. 
Things you should know about avian influenza: 
  • H7 bird flu is a highly contagious disease that infects chickens, ducks, geese, turkeys, guinea fowl, quail, pheasants and ostriches. Many species of wild birds, including waterfowl and seabirds, can also carry the virus. 
  • This is different from the H5N1 bird flu strain impacting wildlife in other countries around the world. Australia remains free from H5 bird flu.
  • Movement controls are in place and the infected properties have been quarantined.  These controls prohibit the movement of birds, equipment and products, including manure and eggs, within and out of the control area and restricted area until further notice.  
  • All poultry owners with more than 50 birds in the restricted area are required to house their birds. This applies to the area between Euroa and Longwood.
  • Recreational game bird hunting is not allowed in the restricted or control areas. This includes duck, stubble quail and introduced game bird hunting. 
  • Moving game bird carcasses and any equipment associated with game bird hunting into, out of or through the restricted and control areas is prohibited unless under a movement permit. 
  • You can find more information about movement controls and quarantine here: agriculture.vic.gov.au/avianinfluenza.
  • To stop the spread of H7 bird flu, birds on infected properties are being destroyed. 
  • Eggs and poultry products from supermarkets are safe to consume.  
All bird owners should regularly check their birds. Unexplained illness or deaths in your birds should be notified to your local vet or by calling the VicEmergency hotline on 1800 226 226.

If you are located within the warning area and you own birds, you must follow all movement controls.
What you should do:
  • Follow the movement controls. Check the Agriculture Victoria website or call 1800 226 226 for detailed information on what you can and cant do in the restricted and control areas.  
If you own birds: 
  • Do not move your birds, eggs, chicken manure or poultry equipment into, within, or out of the control or restricted areas. 
  • Bird owners should regularly check their birds and immediately report any sudden death or unusual signs of disease to their local vet or call 1800 226 226. 
  • Check the Agriculture Victoria website - agriculture.vic.gov.au/avianinfluenza - or phone 1800 226 226 for details on movement controls. 
To help prevent the spread of disease to your birds you should: 
  • Restrict contact between pet birds, poultry and wild birds. 
  • Prevent access by wild birds to food and water sources for your birds. 
  • Keep equipment and yards or aviaries clean. 
  • Limit visitors to your birds. 
  • Bird owners should wash their hands before and after handling birds. 
Check for signs of avian influenza:
  • Signs of the disease in birds may include: Sudden death. Birds with difficulties breathing, such as coughing, sneezing, or rasping.  
  • Swelling and purple discolouration of the head, comb, wattles and neck. 
  • Rapid drop in eating, drinking and egg production. 
  • Ruffled feathers, dopiness, closed eyes. 
  • Diarrhea. 
  • Occasionally, nervous symptoms. 
How avian influenza spreads:
  • Avian influenza can be spread to other animals by movement of eggs, birds, people handling birds, vehicles and equipment between farms, and by clothing, footwear, aerosols, water, feed, litter, wild birds, biting insects and vermin. 
Protecting your health: 
  • Eggs and poultry products from supermarkets are safe to consume.
  • You can find more information here: https://www2.health.vic.gov.au/public-health/infectious-diseases/disease-information-advice/avian-flu
This message was issued by Agriculture Victoria.

The next update is expected by 19/03/2025 05:00 pm or as the situation changes.

Use multiple sources to stay informed: 
  • www.emergency.vic.gov.au
  • VicEmergency Hotline - freecall 1800 226 226
  • VicEmergency app
  • Facebook or Twitter
  • Tune in to ABC Local Radio, commercial and designated community radio stations, or Sky News TV.
Accessibility: 
The following services can help you, or someone you know, access information during an emergency. 
  • To access this information in other languages call the Translating and Interpreting Service on 131 450 (freecall) and ask them to call VicEmergency Hotline.  
  • If you are deaf, hard of hearing, or have a speech/communication impairment contact the National Relay Service and ask them to call the VicEmergency Hotline.

Things you should know about avian influenza: - H7 bird flu is a highly contagious disease that infects chickens, ducks, geese, turkeys, guinea fowl, quail, pheasants and ostriches. Many species of wild birds, including waterfowl and seabirds, can also carry the virus. - This is different from the H5N1 bird flu strain impacting wildlife in other countries around the world. Australia remains free from H5 bird flu. - Movement controls are in place and the infected properties have been quarantined. These controls prohibit the movement of birds, equipment and products, including manure and eggs, within and out of the control area and restricted area until further notice. - All poultry owners with more than 50 birds in the restricted area are required to house their birds. This applies to the area between Euroa and Longwood. - Recreational game bird hunting is not allowed in the restricted or control areas. This includes duck, stubble quail and introduced game bird hunting. - Moving game bird carcasses and any equipment associated with game bird hunting into, out of or through the restricted and control areas is prohibited unless under a movement permit. - You can find more information about movement controls and quarantine here: agriculture.vic.gov.au/avianinfluenza. - To stop the spread of H7 bird flu, birds on infected properties are being destroyed. - Eggs and poultry products from supermarkets are safe to consume. All bird owners should regularly check their birds. Unexplained illness or deaths in your birds should be notified to your local vet or by calling the VicEmergency hotline on 1800 226 226. If you are located within the warning area and you own birds, you must follow all movement controls.

properties.name: Watch & Act
properties.location: Billabong, Howitt Plains, Arbuckle, Reynard, Tamboritha, Wongungarra, Wonnangatta
properties.webBody:
This Watch and Act message is being issued for Arbuckle, Billabong, Howitt Plains, Reynard, Tamboritha, Wongungarra, Wonnangatta.
  • There is a bushfire at Wonnangatta Valley that is not yet under control. 
  • The bushfire is travelling from the Wonnangatta Valley in a westerly direction towards the Howitt Road. 
Don't wait, leaving the area now is the safest option - conditions may change and get worse very quickly. Emergency services may not be able to help you if you decide to stay. 
What you should do: 
  • Monitor changes to the situation. Increased wind speed, change in wind direction, smoke or poor visibility can indicate the situation is changing.
  • Protect yourself and your family. 
  • When driving, slow down, turn on your headlights and watch for emergency service vehicles. Smoke will make it difficult to see.


Impacts in your area: 
All access to the Wonnangatta Valley is closed.  

The following roads, tracks an destinations are closed:
  • Zeka Spur Track
  • Herne Spur Track
  • Wonnangatta Track between Herne Spur and Rileys Track
  • Humphrey River Track south of Wombat Range
  • Howitt Road 
  • Bryces Gorge and Guys Hut
  • Caledonia River Track
  • Butcher Country Track
  • King Billy Track
This message was issued by Forest Fire Management Victoria.

The next update is expected by 10/03/2025 12:00 pm or as the situation changes.

Use multiple sources to stay informed: 
  • www.emergency.vic.gov.au
  • VicEmergency Hotline - freecall 1800 226 226
  • VicEmergency app
  • Facebook or Twitter (#vicfires)
  • Tune in to ABC Local Radio, commercial and designated community radio stations, or Sky News TV.
Accessibility:
The following services can help you, or someone you know, access information during an emergency.
  • To access this information in other languages call the Translating and Interpreting Service on 131 450 (freecall) and ask them to call VicEmergency Hotline.
  • If you are deaf, hard of hearing, or have a speech/communication impairment contact National Relay Service for assistance and ask them to call the VicEmergency Hotline.
properties.text:

More details at http://emergency.vic.gov.au/respond/#!/warning/37094/moreinfo

- There is a bushfire at Wonnangatta Valley that is not yet under control. 
- The bushfire is travelling from the Wonnangatta Valley in a westerly direction towards the Howitt Road.  


Don't wait, leaving the area now is the safest option - conditions may change and get worse very quickly. Emergency services may not be able to help you if you decide to stay.

properties.location: Boho, Warrenbayne, Baddaginnie, Boho South, Marraweeney
properties.webBody:
This Community Information message is being issued for Baddaginnie, Boho, Boho South, Marraweeney, Warrenbayne. 
  • There is a bushfire in the Strathbogie State Forest. 
  • Firefighters are working to fully extinguish this fire.
  • Smoke may be visible from nearby communities and roads. 
  • This Community Information replaces the Advice Message issued at 10:00am 6th March 2025.
There is no immediate threat to the community and no action is required.
This message was issued by Forest Fire Management Victoria.

The next update is expected by 11/03/2025 10:00 am or as the situation changes.

Use multiple sources to stay informed: 
  • www.emergency.vic.gov.au

  • Facebook or Twitter (#vicfires).
  • Tune in to ABC Local Radio, commercial and designated community radio stations, or Sky News TV.
